p: HIV-1 circulates globally as different genetically defined subtypes, although the subtype prevalence varies across different countries; subtype C is most prevalent in Africa (and globally), the circulating recombinant form 01_AE (CRF01_AE) is most prevalent in Southeast Asia, and subtype B is most prevalent in the USA, Europe, and Australia [ 8]. This is of current importance because the HIV-1 epidemic in Australia is experiencing a shift in subtype incidence with a major increase in non-B infections, as an estimated 20% of all new infections in Australia were of non-B origin in 2006, and that increased to 38% in 2016 [ 9]. CRF01_AE is of particular interest for Australia due to the close proximity to Southeast Asia, with both travel and migration between these regions representing a conduit for HIV-1 importation [ 10]. Yet, little is known about the geographic origins and epidemiological characteristics of CRF01_AE in Australia.
